Carrier Pigeons: In the event of an electronic communication blackout, carrier pigeons could be used as a reliable and ancient means of communication. Carrier pigeons have been used for centuries to transmit messages over long distances, and they can fly faster than any other bird, reaching speeds of up to 80 km/h. You could train a pigeon to carry a small message attached to its leg, and it could be released at the destination, where the recipient could retrieve the message.

Homing Pigeons: Similar to carrier pigeons, homing pigeons are trained to return to their home location, and they could be used to transmit messages over long distances. Homing pigeons have an innate ability to navigate and find their way back home, even when released in unfamiliar locations. You could train a homing pigeon to carry a small message and release it at the destination, where the recipient could retrieve the message.

Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Tags: RFID tags are small electronic devices that can be attached to objects and used to track their location. In the event of an electronic communication blackout, RFID tags could be used to track the location of people or objects in real-time. By attaching an RFID tag to a person or object, you could track its location using a handheld RFID reader, even if other forms of communication are unavailable.

Mirror Signals: In the absence of electronic communication, you could use mirrors to signal messages to someone in another country. By using mirrors to reflect sunlight, you could create a signal that could be seen from a distance, allowing you to communicate with someone in another location. This method would be most effective during the daytime when the sun is visible, and the recipient could use a mirror to reflect the signal back to you.

Smoke Signals: In ancient times, smoke signals were used to communicate over long distances.
